chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Boils and carbuncles
chapter.summary: Covers the management of boils and carbuncles, including when to prescribe antibiotics and when to incise and drain.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 1 month onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I admit or refer a person with a boil or carbuncle?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Assess for the presence of discharging pus and fluctuance.
    • In early infection, it may be difficult to decide whether pus is present.
  • Arrange for urgent same-day incision and drainage for:
    • All fluctuant boils, unless they are small, (in which case they will usually drain spontaneously after application of moist heat. See Acute boils or carbuncles.
    • All fluctuant carbuncles.
  • Incision and drainage may sometimes be performed in primary care if the lesion is small and the expertise and facilities are available. Otherwise, the person should be referred to a surgical unit or emergency department, according to local protocol.
  • If incision and drainage are carried out in primary care, the lesion should be covered with a sterile dressing afterwards, as this helps to prevent autoinoculation.
  • Consider admission for intravenous antibiotics if the person:
    • Is systemically unwell.
    • Has cellulitis. For more information, see the CKS topic on Cellulitis - acute.
    • Has an infection in an area where complications can be serious (such as the face).
    • Is immunocompromised as a result of an underlying disease (such as diabetes) or medication (such as corticosteroids).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice. The decision on whether to urgently refer or admit the person will depend on clinical judgment, taking into account the rapidity and degree of spread; any underlying medical conditions, particularly those causing immunosuppression; and whether the person (or carer) is able to follow instructions reliably regarding monitoring of complications.

  • Incision and drainage of all fluctuant boils and carbuncles is recommended on the basis of expert opinion in Practice guidelines for the diagnosis and management of skin and soft-tissue infections, published by the Infectious Diseases Society of America [Stevens et al, 2014]. These guidelines also recommend covering the drained lesion with a dry dressing.
  • It is important to consider admission in people who have systemic symptoms suggesting local or systemic spread of infection, as serious complications, including sepsis, may develop at any time.

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I take a swab from a person with a boil or carbuncle?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Consider taking a swab of pus from the contents of the lesion if:
    • The boil or carbuncle is:
      • Not responding to treatment.
      • Persistent or recurrent, to exclude atypical mycobacteria or PVL-SA.
    • There are multiple lesions.
    • The person:
      • Is immunocompromised.
      • Is known to be colonized with MRSA.
      • Has diabetes.
  • If PVL-SA is suspected, this should be mentioned specifically on the laboratory form.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the expert opinion of our reviewers, including those from the British Association of Dermatologists.

Including PVL-SA on the laboratory form
  • This is based on expert opinion in an article [Fogo, 2011]. PVL gene detection is not routinely tested in the UK, and antibiotic sensitivities cannot reliably discriminate between PVL positive and negative strains of S. aureus.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with an acute non-fluctuant boil or carbuncle in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Advise the person to apply moist heat three to four times a day to alleviate pain, localize the infection, and hasten the drainage of pus. 
  • Advise the person to seek medical advice if the boil or carbuncle becomes fluctuant, as they may need incision and drainage.
    • However, a small boil may drain spontaneously.
    • Once spontaneous drainage has occurred, the lesion should be covered with a sterile dressing, to help prevent autoinoculation.
  • Advise the person to seek urgent medical advice if they become systemically unwell or develop cellulitis.
  • Seek specialist advice if there is a possibility or confirmation of:
    • PVL-SA. Suspect particularly in people with severe or recurrent boils.
    • MRSA.
  • Prescribe a 7-day course of oral antibiotics if the person does not need admission but:
    • The person has a fever.
    • The person has cellulitis (see the CKS topic on Cellulitis - acute).
    • The lesion is on the face.
    • The lesion is a carbuncle.
    • The person is in pain or severe discomfort.
    • There are other comorbidities (such as diabetes or immunosuppression).
      • Flucloxacillin is recommended first line (erythromycin [preferred in pregnancy and breastfeeding] or clarithromycin are alternatives if the person has a true allergy to penicillin). For further information on prescribing antibiotics, see prescribing information.
  • Give information and self-care advice. Offer written information, such as the British Association of Dermatologists patient information leaflet on boils. Advise the person to:
    • Take paracetamol or ibuprofen as required for pain relief. For more information, see the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain and NSAIDs - prescribing issues.
    • Maintain good personal hygiene.
    • Wash hands carefully after contact with lesions.
    • Wash and tumble dry underclothes, bed linen, and towels at a high temperature daily (if possible) to prevent spreading the infection to other parts of their body, or to other people.
    • Use a separate face cloth and towel.
    • Wear loose-fitting, lightweight clothes as much as possible.
    • Keep wounds or grazes clean and covered with sterile gauze until they heal.
    • Seal and discard used gauze or dressings immediately. If purulent drainage collects, gauze or dressings should be changed frequently.
    • Do not participate in contact sports, or visit a swimming pool or gym until the boil has cleared, to avoid passing the infection on to others.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Application of moist heat to aid drainage
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in Practice guidelines for the diagnosis and management of skin and soft-tissue infections, published by the Infectious Diseases Society of America [Stevens et al, 2005]; a textbook [Craft, 2012]; and a clinical review [Riain, 2013]. 
When to seek medical advice
  • These recommendations are based on what CKS considers to be good medical practice.
Seeking specialist advice for possible or confirmed infection with PVL-SA or MRSA
  • These recommendations are based on what CKS considers to be good medical practice.
  • Expert reviewers from the British Association of Dermatologists emphasized the importance of considering infection with PVL-SA in people with severe or recurrent boils.
Prescribing antibiotics for boils and carbuncles 
  • The recommendations for whom to prescribe antibiotics to are pragmatic, based on the most likely causative organism (S. aureus) and expert opinion from the medical literature [Ladhani and Garbash, 2005; Stevens et al, 2005; Craft, 2012].
    • It is uncertain whether antibiotics should be used to treat all boils, as CKS could find no trial evidence. Expert opinion from the CKS expert reviewers suggests that antibiotics are not always necessary, but should be particularly considered if the lesion is large (for example carbuncles) or there is associated fever or surrounding cellulitis, there are other comorbidities (for example diabetes), or complications are more likely because of the site (for example cavernous sinus thrombosis can result from boils on the face). For more information, see Complications.
    • Most cases can be treated in primary care provided the person is closely monitored for signs of systemic upset.
Choice of antibiotics
  • The recommendations on the choice of antibiotics are based on expert in review articles [Stulberg et al, 2002; Finch et al, 2003; Riain, 2013] and extrapolated from a guideline published by Public Health England [PHE, 2015].
    • Flucloxacillin is recommended as the first-line treatment because it has a narrow spectrum of activity and is active against most Gram-positive cocci, including beta-lactamase–producing staphylococci and streptococci [Stulberg et al, 2002; Finch et al, 2003; Riain, 2013]. It diffuses well into most tissues and is therefore suitable for skin and soft-tissue infections [Finch et al, 2003].
    • Erythromycin and clarithromycin are suitable alternatives to flucloxacillin in people who have a true allergy to penicillin. They are macrolide antibiotics with a broad spectrum of activity against most sensitive Gram-positive cocci (including staphylococci and streptococci) [Stulberg et al, 2002; Finch et al, 2003; Riain, 2013].
      • Erythromycin is preferred for pregnant and breastfeeding women as there is more experience with its use than with clarithromycin and most studies do not suggest an association with erythromycin use in pregnancy and adverse effects on the fetus. Only small amounts of erythromycin are present in breast milk and it is not known to be harmful [BNF 72, 2016].
      • Clarithromycin is generally thought to be better tolerated than erythromycin [Riain, 2013], and also has a more convenient dosing regimen [BNF 72, 2016]. 
Length of antibiotics course
  • These recommendations are extrapolated from an antibiotics guideline produced by Public Health England [PHE, 2015].
    • PHE did not consider the treatment of boils and carbuncles but for other bacterial skin infections, such as impetigo and cellulitis, the Health Protection Agency recommends a duration of 7 days for empirical antibiotic treatment.
  • CKS found no randomized controlled trials that studied the effectiveness of antibiotic treatment (or the length of antibiotic course needed) for the treatment of boils and carbuncles.
Self-care advice
  • Self-care recommendations are based on expert opinion in Practice guidelines for the diagnosis and management of skin and soft-tissue Infections, published by the Infectious Diseases Society of America [Stevens et al, 2005], a textbook [Craft, 2012] and a patient information leaflet published by the British Association of Dermatologists [BAD, 2016].
    • Good personal hygiene will reduce the number of S. aureus organisms on the skin and prevent re-infection.
    • A large number of staphylococci are frequently present on sheets and clothes of people with boils (or carbuncles). Carefully washing clothes and sheets, and not sharing clothes and towels, may reduce the chances of re-infection or the chances of spreading the infection to friends and family members.
    • Used dressings and gauze should be discarded appropriately to avoid spreading the infection further. Frequent changing of dressings, especially if purulent drainage collects, is recommended for the same reason.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage recurrent boils and carbuncles?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Exclude and manage other underlying causes where appropriate, for example:
    • Systemic disorders (such as diabetes).
    • Obesity
    • Skin disease (such as eczema).
    • Localized predisposing factors (such as pressure from tight clothing).
    • Treatment with corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive drugs.
  • Ask the person whether they have had close personal contact with an infected person, such as a family member, or through contact sports.
  • Ask the person whether they or a family member works in a hospital or other healthcare setting, as recurrence could be due to staphylococcal carriage.
  • Swab the lesion (to confirm the causative organism and antibiotic sensitivities) and treat with the appropriate antibiotics for 7 days.
  • If PVL-SA infection is suspected, specifically mention this on the laboratory form. 
    • If staphylococcal infection is confirmed, check for carriage of S. aureus and manage accordingly. See Scenario: Staphylococcal carriage.
    • If the person is already known to have MRSA infection or the swab sample of pus grows MRSA, see the CKS topic on MRSA in primary care for further information.
    • If PVL-SA infection is confirmed, management should be discussed with microbiology or the local infection control team.
  • Reinforce self-care advice where appropriate.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Excluding underlying conditions
  • These recommendations are based on expert opinion published in textbooks [Pasternack and Swartz, 2010; Craft, 2012] and on the expert opinion of CKS reviewers, including those from the British Association of Dermatologists.
Close contact
  • Expert opinion in a textbook is that close contact with a family member with an infected lesion or through contact sports is a risk factor for recurrent boils [Craft, 2012].
If the person works in hospital or healthcare setting
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion published in textbooks [Hay and Adriaans, 2004; Blaser, 2010], and on the expert opinion of CKS reviewers, including those from the British Association of Dermatologists.
    • The textbooks advise that if a boil or carbuncle is recurrent, it may be prudent to exclude other underlying causes, such as nasal and perineal carriage of Staphylococcus aureus in the person and their household [Hay and Adriaans, 2004; Blaser, 2010].
  • Staphylococcal carriage is common in healthcare workers [Craft, 2012].
Swabbing the lesion
  • These recommendations are based on the expert opinion of CKS reviewers, including those from the British Association of Dermatologists.
Length of antibiotics course
  • These recommendations are extrapolated from an antibiotics guideline produced by Public Health England [PHE, 2015].
    • PHE did not consider the treatment of boils and carbuncles but for other bacterial skin infections, such as impetigo and cellulitis, they recommend a duration of 7 days for empirical antibiotic treatment. PHE also recommends antibiotic treatment for 5-7 days for moderate skin and soft tissue infections, such as abscesses >5 cm, caused by PVL-SA [HPA, 2008b].
  • CKS found no randomized controlled trials that studied the effectiveness of antibiotic treatment (or the length of antibiotic course needed) for the treatment of boils and carbuncles.
